title: Rugby World Cup: England vs France off because of Typhoon Hagibis
text:
England’s final Rugby World Cup group game has been called off (Getty Images)

England’s final Rugby World Cup group match against France has been cancelled because of Typhoon Hagibis, while Scotland’s crucial fixture against hosts Japan is in doubt.

The typhoon is predicted to be one of the most violent in recent history and could cause huge damage in Tokyo.

Both England vs France and New Zealand vs Italy have been called off, but Ireland’s match with Samoa in Fukuoka on Saturday is expected to go ahead.

Typhoon Hagibis is expected to be one of the most violent in recent history (EPA)

The Rugby World Cup’s tournament director Alan Gilpin said: ‘The decision to cancel matches has not been taken lightly.

‘It has been made with the best interest of team, public, and tournament volunteer safety as a priority based on expert advice.’

WHAT HAS BEEN ANNOUNCED SO FAR CANCELLED: England vs France (Saturday); New Zealand vs Italy (Saturday).

ON: Australia vs Georgia (Friday); Ireland vs Samoa (Saturday) both set to go ahead.

IN DOUBT: Four games on Sunday – including Scotland vs Japan. A review will be made on Sunday morning.

Scotland’s crucial final match in Pool A is against Japan on Sunday and they must beat the tournament hosts to stand a chance of reaching the quarter-finals.

If the game were to be cancelled, both Scotland and Japan would be awarded two points.

But if Ireland beat Samoa, two points from Scotland’s cancelled match would not be enough to see them through.

A Scottish Rugby spokesman said in response to the potential cancellation of their fixture: ‘We are in regular dialogue with World Rugby at all levels to work to ensure our fixture against Japan on Sunday can be played as planned. Public safety is the clear priority.

‘With potential impact on our last Pool A fixture, Scottish Rugby fully expects contingency plans to be put in place to enable Scotland to contest for a place in the quarter-finals on the pitch, and will be flexible to accommodate this.’
